Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer breached duty of fairness or natural justice in determining dependant child status
Evidence_Assessment: Sufficient evidence supported the officer's decision
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate unreasonableness or procedural unfairness
Credibility_Factor: Applicants' enrollment records and study patterns assessed
Legal_Rule: A 'dependant child' must be continuously enrolled and attending an accredited post-secondary institution full-time after age 22
Procedural_Issue: Alleged breach of duty of fairness or natural justice
Grounds_for_Claim: Visa officer's determination that siblings were not dependant children
Review_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied by Federal Court
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Court found no breach of procedural fairness
Key_Evidence_Considered: Enrollment history, nature of studies, gaps in education, private home study
Legal_Framework: IRPA and principles of administrative law including natural justice
Applicant_Challenge: Challenging exclusion from dependant child status
Defendant_Response: Decision based on interpretation of IRPA and factual record
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of enrollment and educational records
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Remedy_Sought: Declaration that decision was unreasonable or procedurally unfair
Claimant_Status: Applicants were siblings seeking dependant child status
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Failure to meet continuous full-time enrollment requirement after age 22
Applicable_Process: Immigration application process with post-submission judicial review
Governing_Rule: Dependant child must be continuously enrolled in full-time studies at accredited institution post-age 22
